Booking hotels and tours can be a breeze, but understanding how addresses are written can be a real head-scratcher. Let me share some insights from my own travel adventures.

unnormalised: First things first, addresses in India are generally written in a hierarchical order. Think small to big. You'll usually see the house number or building name first, followed by the street or locality. For example, you might see something like "House No. 123, Krishna Nagar". Then comes the area or sub-locality. This could be "Sector 15" in a planned city like Noida, or maybe "Bandra West" in Mumbai. The city then follows, like "Delhi", "Mumbai", or "Chennai".

You will usually see the house number or building name first, followed by the street or locality. For example, you might see something like "House Number one hundred and twenty three, Krishna Nagar". Then comes the area or sub-locality. This could be "Sector fifteen" in a planned city like Noida, or maybe "Bandra West" in Mumbai. The city then follows, like "Delhi", "Mumbai", or "Chennai".

unnormalised: Next up, the postal code, also known as a PIN code. This is super important for accurate delivery. It's a 6-digit number, like "110001" for New Delhi's Connaught Place or "400001" for Mumbai's Colaba. Always double-check the PIN code when booking! It helps ensure your online shopping (those beautiful sarees you just have to buy!) reaches the right place, especially if you are shipping it to your hotel.
normalised: Next up, the postal code, also known as a P-I-N code. This is super important for accurate delivery. It is a six-digit number, like "one hundred and ten thousand and one" for New Delhi's Connaught Place or "four hundred thousand and one" for Mumbai's Colaba. Always double-check the P-I-N code when booking! It helps ensure your online shopping (those beautiful sarees you just have to buy!) reaches the right place, especially if you are shipping it to your hotel.

unnormalised: Now, here's where it gets interesting when it comes to hotels. You might see the hotel address listed as "The Oberoi, 443 Udyog Vihar Phase V, Gurgaon, Haryana, 122016". Here, "The Oberoi" is the hotel name, "443 Udyog Vihar Phase V" is the location details, "Gurgaon" is the city, "Haryana" is the state and "122016" is the all important postal code. Don't forget the state – it helps narrow things down! Keep an eye out for "Near [Landmark]" too; often a hotel will say "Near India Gate" or "Opposite Marine Drive." Very handy for taxi drivers!

Don't forget the state – it helps narrow things down! Keep an eye out for "Near [Landmark]" too; often a hotel will say "Near India Gate" or "Opposite Marine Drive." Very handy for taxi drivers!

unnormalised: When booking online, many sites will have fields for each part of the address separately: "Building Name," "Street Address," "City," "State," "PIN Code." Be extra careful when filling them out, especially if you're using a foreign credit card. Banks can sometimes flag transactions if the billing address doesn't perfectly match what they have on file. And believe me, you don't want a cancelled hotel booking because of an address hiccup!

unnormalised: Also, just a little tip for international visitors: it's common to include a phone number on any delivery information. Putting down "+91 [Your Indian phone number or the hotel's number]" will avoid issues when parcels can't be delivered.
